abstract.p: Natural Point TrackIR2 enhances flight simulator games using device that follows head movement by tracking dot placed on forehead; photo (M)

block.p: Flight simulator software has its limits. You can use your joystick to raise the wing flaps or open the throttle, but looking out a side window involves pushing a knob, which is certainly not what pilots do in a real plane. A new device from Natural Point, TrackIR2, makes simulation just a little more realistic by enabling you to look around your virtual plane just by turning your head.

Unlike tracking devices that require you to wear a headset to broadcast your head movements to your computer, the TrackIR2 uses an infrared device that rests on your monitor and tracks head movements by means of a reflective dot that you place on your forehead or a hat. The device, available for $129 at www.trackir.com, translates a small movement of the head into a much larger movement on screen, so turning an inch to the right is enough to look out the right window of your cockpit, and two inches is enough to twist your virtual view 180 degrees to face the rear.
